trans-unit.source: Develop Python MapReduce jobs with HDInsight | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Develop Python MapReduce jobs with HDInsight | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create and run Python MapReduce jobs on Linux-based HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create and run Python MapReduce jobs on Linux-based HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: Hadoop provides a streaming API for MapReduce that enables you to write map and reduce functions in languages other than Java.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop provides a streaming API for MapReduce that enables you to write map and reduce functions in languages other than Java.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn how to use Python to perform MapReduce operations.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn how to use Python to perform MapReduce operations.

trans-unit.source: While the Python code in this document can be used with a Windows-based HDInsight cluster, the steps in this document are specific to Linux-based clusters.
trans-unit.target: While the Python code in this document can be used with a Windows-based HDInsight cluster, the steps in this document are specific to Linux-based clusters.

trans-unit.source: This article is based on information and examples published by Michael Noll at [http://www.michael-noll.com/tutorials/writing-an-hadoop-mapreduce-program-in-python/](Writing an Hadoop MapReduce Program in Python).
trans-unit.target: This article is based on information and examples published by Michael Noll at [http://www.michael-noll.com/tutorials/writing-an-hadoop-mapreduce-program-in-python/](Writing an Hadoop MapReduce Program in Python).

trans-unit.source: To complete the steps in this article, you will need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete the steps in this article, you will need the following:

trans-unit.source: A Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight cluster
trans-unit.target: A Linux-based Hadoop on HDInsight cluster

trans-unit.source: A text editor
trans-unit.target: A text editor

trans-unit.source: For Windows clients, PuTTY and PSCP.
trans-unit.target: For Windows clients, PuTTY and PSCP.

trans-unit.source: These utilities are available from the PuTTY Download Page.
trans-unit.target: These utilities are available from the PuTTY Download Page.

trans-unit.source: For this example, you will implement a basic word count by using a mapper and reducer.
trans-unit.target: For this example, you will implement a basic word count by using a mapper and reducer.

trans-unit.source: The mapper breaks sentences into individual words, and the reducer aggregates the words and counts to produce the output.
trans-unit.target: The mapper breaks sentences into individual words, and the reducer aggregates the words and counts to produce the output.

trans-unit.source: The following flowchart illustrates what happens during the map and reduce phases.
trans-unit.target: The following flowchart illustrates what happens during the map and reduce phases.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>illustration of map reduce</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>illustration of map reduce</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Python is a general-purpose, high-level programming language that allows you to express concepts in fewer lines of code than many other languages.
trans-unit.target: Python is a general-purpose, high-level programming language that allows you to express concepts in fewer lines of code than many other languages.

trans-unit.source: It has recently became popular with data scientists as a prototyping language because its interpreted nature, dynamic typing, and elegant syntax make it suitable for rapid application development.
trans-unit.target: It has recently became popular with data scientists as a prototyping language because its interpreted nature, dynamic typing, and elegant syntax make it suitable for rapid application development.

trans-unit.source: Python is installed on all HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: Python is installed on all HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: Hadoop allows you to specify a file that contains the map and reduce logic that is used by a job.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop allows you to specify a file that contains the map and reduce logic that is used by a job.

trans-unit.source: The specific requirements for the map and reduce logic are:
trans-unit.target: The specific requirements for the map and reduce logic are:

trans-unit.source: Input: The map and reduce components must read input data from STDIN.
trans-unit.target: Input: The map and reduce components must read input data from STDIN.

trans-unit.source: Output: The map and reduce components must write output data to STDOUT.
trans-unit.target: Output: The map and reduce components must write output data to STDOUT.

trans-unit.source: Data format: The data consumed and produced must be a key/value pair, separated by a tab character.
trans-unit.target: Data format: The data consumed and produced must be a key/value pair, separated by a tab character.

trans-unit.source: Python can easily handle these requirements by using the sys module to read from STDIN and using print to print to STDOUT.
trans-unit.target: Python can easily handle these requirements by using the sys module to read from STDIN and using print to print to STDOUT.

trans-unit.source: The remaining task is simply formatting the data with a tab (\t) character between the key and value.
trans-unit.target: The remaining task is simply formatting the data with a tab (\t) character between the key and value.

trans-unit.source: The mapper and reducer are text files, in this case mapper.py and reducer.py (to make it clear which does what).
trans-unit.target: The mapper and reducer are text files, in this case mapper.py and reducer.py (to make it clear which does what).

trans-unit.source: You can create these by using the editor of your choice.
trans-unit.target: You can create these by using the editor of your choice.

trans-unit.source: Create a new file named mapper.py and use the following code as the content:
trans-unit.target: Create a new file named mapper.py and use the following code as the content:

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to read through the code so you can understand what it does.
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to read through the code so you can understand what it does.

trans-unit.source: Create a new file named reducer.py and use the following code as the content:
trans-unit.target: Create a new file named reducer.py and use the following code as the content:

trans-unit.source: Both mapper.py and reducer.py must be on the head node of the cluster before we can run them.
trans-unit.target: Both mapper.py and reducer.py must be on the head node of the cluster before we can run them.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to upload them is to use scp (pscp if you are using a Windows client).
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to upload them is to use scp (pscp if you are using a Windows client).

trans-unit.source: From the client, in the same directory as mapper.py and reducer.py, use the following command.
trans-unit.target: From the client, in the same directory as mapper.py and reducer.py, use the following command.

trans-unit.source: Replace username with an SSH user, and clustername with the name of your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Replace username with an SSH user, and clustername with the name of your cluster.

trans-unit.source: This copies the files from the local system to the head node.
trans-unit.target: This copies the files from the local system to the head node.

trans-unit.source: If you used a password to secure your SSH account, you will be prompted for the password.
trans-unit.target: If you used a password to secure your SSH account, you will be prompted for the password.

trans-unit.source: If you used an SSH key, you may have to use the -i parameter and the path to the private key, for example, scp -i /path/to/private/key mapper.py reducer.py username@clustername-ssh.azurehdinsight.net:.
trans-unit.target: If you used an SSH key, you may have to use the -i parameter and the path to the private key, for example, scp -i /path/to/private/key mapper.py reducer.py username@clustername-ssh.azurehdinsight.net:.

trans-unit.source: Connect to the cluster by using SSH:
trans-unit.target: Connect to the cluster by using SSH:

trans-unit.source: If you used a password to secure your SSH account, you will be prompted for the password.
trans-unit.target: If you used a password to secure your SSH account, you will be prompted for the password.

trans-unit.source: If you used an SSH key, you may have to use the -i parameter and the path to the private key, for example, ssh -i /path/to/private/key username@clustername-ssh.azurehdinsight.net.
trans-unit.target: If you used an SSH key, you may have to use the -i parameter and the path to the private key, for example, ssh -i /path/to/private/key username@clustername-ssh.azurehdinsight.net.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to start the MapReduce job.
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to start the MapReduce job.

trans-unit.source: This command has the following parts:
trans-unit.target: This command has the following parts:

trans-unit.source: hadoop-streaming.jar: Used when performing streaming MapReduce operations.
trans-unit.target: hadoop-streaming.jar: Used when performing streaming MapReduce operations.

trans-unit.source: It interfaces Hadoop with the external MapReduce code you provide.
trans-unit.target: It interfaces Hadoop with the external MapReduce code you provide.

trans-unit.source: -files: Tells Hadoop that the specified files are needed for this MapReduce job, and they should be copied to all the worker nodes.
trans-unit.target: -files: Tells Hadoop that the specified files are needed for this MapReduce job, and they should be copied to all the worker nodes.

trans-unit.source: -mapper: Tells Hadoop which file to use as the mapper.
trans-unit.target: -mapper: Tells Hadoop which file to use as the mapper.

trans-unit.source: -reducer: Tells Hadoop which file to use as the reducer.
trans-unit.target: -reducer: Tells Hadoop which file to use as the reducer.

trans-unit.source: -input: The input file that we should count words from.
trans-unit.target: -input: The input file that we should count words from.

trans-unit.source: -output: The directory that the output will be written to.
trans-unit.target: -output: The directory that the output will be written to.

trans-unit.source: This directory will be created by the job.
trans-unit.target: This directory will be created by the job.

trans-unit.source: You should see a bunch of INFO statements as the job starts, and finally see the map and reduce operation displayed as percentages.
trans-unit.target: You should see a bunch of INFO statements as the job starts, and finally see the map and reduce operation displayed as percentages.

trans-unit.source: You will receive status information about the job when it completes.
trans-unit.target: You will receive status information about the job when it completes.

trans-unit.source: When the job is complete, use the following command to view the output:
trans-unit.target: When the job is complete, use the following command to view the output:

trans-unit.source: This should display a list of words and how many times the word occurred.
trans-unit.target: This should display a list of words and how many times the word occurred.

trans-unit.target: The following is an sample of the output data:
